newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Philips profits rise in consumer turnaround.
newsitem.headline: Philips profits rise in consumer turnaround.

text.p: Philips Electronics NV said Wednesday that first-quarter profit jumped 22 percent as its consumer products unit swung back into the plus column in what it described as a sustainable recovery.

Europe's biggest consumer electronics group said net profit from normal operations climbed to 460 million guilders ($239 million) from 377 million, with the removal of loss-making German unit Grundig from the operating results making a significant impact.
Operating profit in the first quarter rose 21 percent and sales grew 3 percent to 16.14 billion guilders ($8.39 billion).
"Grundig's out, that in itself makes for a significantly better picture," Vice Chairman Dudley Eustace told a news conference.
But he added fundamental changes in the heart of the consumer products division were also bearing fruit after the huge restructuring begun last year.
"The first-quarter results provide us with the confidence that we are on track following the improvement programme started in 1996," Philips said in a statement.
The Philips consumer products unit, which includes Grundig and Sound & Vision, turned in an operating profit vs. a loss a year earlier.

The electronics giant said at the beginning of 1997 that it would no longer absorb 100 percent of Grundig's losses. Instead it would become a passive minority shareholder, booking Grundig's results under income from unconsolidated companies in proportion to Philips' 31.6 percent stake.
But Philips' semiconductor unit, a main profit centre in recent years, saw operating earnings fall almost 14 percent.
Philips said sales had stagnated year-on-year, but added "this reflects an upward trend in performance compared with the fourth quarter of 1996."
Analysts' initial reactions to the net profit figure -- which came in well ahead of consensus expectations guilders -- were positive, albeit cautious.
"We are extremely pleased with this result and the progress that has been booked in this first quarter," ING Barings' Steven Vrolijk said.
But Delta Lloyd Bank's Peter Wortel was less upbeat. "Looking simply at the figures, it's good," he said. "Looking deeper...we had expected semiconductors to do better. In fact they're lower."
